Title(s): La Male Regle de T. Hoccleue
_description: Thomas Hoccleve, La Male Regle de T. Hoccleue — fifty-six 8-line stanzas

CantFrag.First Lines:
I haue her[.] said of men ful [..]re agoThat pros[......] ys blynd
                    ande se ne mayAnde ver[.]fye y may wel hit is so[..]r I myself haue
                    put hit in a say…
CantFrag.Last Lines:
…hyt syttyth a god to be of grace freeffor yeue me lord and i
                    no more wole trespace
CantFrag.Note:
Foliation refers to the most recent (pencil) foliation. Stanzas 5, 6, 9,
                    10, 12, 14, 45, 44, 51 written separately as a ballade, added to flyleaf in the
                    fifteenth century; f. 207 fire-damaged along outer edge, with loss of
                    text.
CantFrag.Attributed Title:
Bala[de] (f. 207v); A balade Anglice (Register P, index to both
                    O and P)
CantFrag.Editions:
Historical Manuscripts Commission Ninth Report: Calendar of the
                Manuscripts of the Most Hon. The Marquis of Salisbury, K. G., etc., preserved at
                Hatfield House, Hertfordshire.
         24 vols. (1883-84, with addenda to 1976): App. 108 (2 stanzas only).
Smith,  Reginald Anthony Lendon. 
             Canterbury Cathedral Priory.
         Cambridge: at the UP, 1943: 198-9 (1 stanza only).
Trudgill,  Marian,  and  J. A. Burrow.  
             “A Hocclevean Balade.” 
             Notes & Queries
         n.s. 45 (1998): 178-80: Lines 57-64 and 49-56 edited, textual variants for
                        all lines given.

HunHM111.First Lines:
O precious tresor inconparableO ground & roote of
                    prosperitee…
HunHM111.Last Lines:
…As may myn hurtes all þat me greeueExyle cleene &
                    voide me of pyne
HunHM111.Attributed Author:
Cy ensuyt la male regle de T. Hoccleue (f.
                    16v)
